en: Interview with Carol Myers of Pi Beta Phi Elementary School. Myers discusses the morning of the fire with regards to the feelings inside the school among faculty and students. She also talks about the challenges faced by her husband an officer with the Gatlinburg Police Department; as well as the difficulties shared by students during the fire and after. This is a representative quote from the interview: "[The fire] would leave buildings perfectly fine, standing, but the building next to it would be burned to the ground. Something would be singed, but something else would be burned."
Individuals (tourists or locals) directly affected by the fire

She also talks about the challenges faced by her husband an officer with the Gatlinburg Police Department; as well as the difficulties shared by students during the fire and after. This is a representative quote from the interview: "[The fire] would leave buildings perfectly fine, standing, but the building next to it would be burned to the ground. Something would be singed, but something else would be burned."

Interview with Carol Myers, 2020-01-11 -- Pittman Center
Interview with Carol Myers, 2020-01-11 -- Pi Beta Phi Elementary School
Can you state your name and tell us a little about yourself?
Can you tell us a little about the Pi Beta Phi Elementary School?
Talking about the transient community, can you tell us about the diversity at the school?
It sounds like the teacher community is also close knit?
What do you do at the school?
Before talking about the day of the fire, what do you remember about the weeks before it?
Tell me about the day of the fire.
What time did you leave that day? Were the students still at the school?
Were you with family in Sevierville?
What news station was set up at the intersection?
When your husband came home, did you two talk?
In the days after the fire, can you talk about the experience of returning to Pi Beta Phi?
Were there any stories that stood out from the students sharing?
Did you receive a lot of cards from other children?
You mentioned some of your coworkers had lost everything, but they were still teaching?
Did you have any children that didn't return in your class?
How was the news broken about the two students that lost their lives?
Did your husband share any thoughts about going back to the police fore after the fire?
The first time that you went back into Gatlinburg, what was that like?
Is there anything more you would like to share about the days and weeks after the wildfire?
Did you feel that Gatlinburg would reestablish itself after the fire?
Did you feel that Gatlinburg would reestablish itself after the fire?
Can you tell me about your assessment of Gatlinburg in these past 3 years?
How do you feel the fires shaped community relations?
How do you feel about the phrase "Mountain Tough" and how it characterizes the community?
Do you feel that this could happen again and have you made any provisions? Has the City?
Do you feel there was anything good that came out of this fire?
Can you share with us any value you see in preserving these stories for the future?
Is there anything  we haven't talked about that you would like to share?
Pi Beta Phi Elementary School discussed in Interview with Carol Myers, 2020-01-11
Sevierville discussed in Interview with Carol Myers, 2020-01-11
